qas.question: What type of signal can be generated by intense enough stimulation of any sensory receptor?
What types of stimuli can't some sensory fibers differentiate between?
What type of stimuli do nociceptors response to?
What does stimuli generate to send signals along a nerve fiber?
How many different types of ion channels have so far been identified?
Who came up with the intensive theory in 1784?
What did Wilhelm Erb come up with in 1784?

plausible_answers.text: that a pain signal can be generated by intense enough stimulation of any sensory receptor

qas.question: What is Erb Wilhelm's intensive theory?
What happened to Erb Wilhelm's theory?
How many different types of nociceptor chemical channels have been identified?

context: <b5_0>Wilhelm Erb<b5_0/>'s (1874) <b6_0>"intensive" theory<b6_0/>, <b7_0>that a <a0_0>pain<a0_0/> signal can be generated by intense enough stimulation of any sensory receptor<b7_0/>, <b8_0>has been soundly disproved.<b8_0/> Some sensory fibers do not differentiate between <a1_0>noxious and non-noxious<a1_0/> stimuli, while others, nociceptors, respond only to <a2_0>noxious, high intensity<a2_0/> stimuli. At the peripheral end of the nociceptor, noxious stimuli generate <a3_0>currents<a3_0/> that, above a given threshold, begin to send signals along the nerve fiber to the spinal cord. The "specificity" (whether it responds to thermal, chemical or mechanical features of its environment) of a nociceptor is determined by which ion channels it expresses at its peripheral end. <a4_0><b9_0>Dozens<b9_0/><a4_0/> of different types of nociceptor ion channels have so far been identified, and their exact functions are still being determined.
